passage.text: Kinetics of paracetamol oxidation by ozone and hydroxyl radicals, formation of transformation products and toxicity
Relevant resource
True|False
Abstract

Paracetamol oxidation by ozonation and H2O2/UV processes was investigated. The second-order rate constant for the reaction of paracetamol with ozone was determined at pH 7.2 (kO3/PRC=2.57×106M-1s-1). The rate constant of the elementary reaction of ozone with the ionized form of PRC was then calculated and the pH dependence of the ozonation reaction of PRC was estimated. The second-order rate constant of the reaction of paracetamol with HO radicals was also determined at pH 5 through the H2O2/UV oxidation system (kHO /PRC=4.94×109M-1s-1). In the light of the high rate constants obtained, two conclusions on the kinetics of paracetamol ozonation in real water were drawn: (i) hydroxyl radicals do not have any impact on the removal of paracetamol during ozonation of real waters; (ii) a half-life of 0.03 s can be estimated for paracetamol, for a residual ozone concentration of 0.4 mg L−1. Hydroquinone and two other ozonation transformation products were identified by LC/UV, LC/MS and MS/MS analyses. In parallel, for the first time, toxicity was measured in ozonated paracetamol solutions with the luminescent bacteria Vibrio fisheri test. The results showed an increase in toxicity as paracetamol degraded. This toxicity could not be assigned to hydroquinone formation only. One or several other transformation products more toxic than paracetamol might be formed.

passage.text: UV characteristics and main fragment ions obtained from MS and MS/MS analyses of PRC and ozonation transformation products.
Figures

Determination of the second-order rate constant kO3/PRC; [O3]0 = 0–6.8 μM; pH = 7.2; T = 20 °C; (a) ln [PRC]T,n/[PRC]T,0 versus ln [PHN]T,n/[PHN]T,0; (b) pH-dependence of the second-order rate constant; symbols ○, Δ and ◊ represent triplicate experiments.
PRC oxidation in the H2O2/UV system and modelling contribution of photolysis (for experiments (a), (b) and (c): [PRC]T,0 = 5 μM; [H2O2]0 = 50 mM; pH = 5; T = 20 °C).
Impact of Rct values on PRC removal at pH 7.2 in real waters.
Proposed pathways for PRC reactions with ozone.
Toxicity (in duplicate) and by-product formation patterns during PRC ozonation; [PRC]T,0 = 1 g L−1; [O3]0 = 6 mg min−1; pH = 7.2; T = 20 °C; (sample dilution: 1/50).
keywords
['Paracetamol', 'Ozonation', 'Hydroxyl radicals', 'Rate constants', 'By-products', 'Toxicity']
Introduction

Pharmaceuticals have been identified as major emerging contaminants due to their presence in natural waters in recent years. This environmental pollution is related to the use of both human and veterinary drugs. Many pharmaceuticals are highly polar, hydrophilic and have been detected in sewage treatment plant effluents, surface and ground waters, and even in drinking waters in several countries . Moreover, recent studies showed that some of them can bioaccumulate in aquatic organisms . Paracetamol (PRC), also known as acetaminophen (pKa PRC = 9.38 ), is widely used as an analgesic and antipyretic drug. PRC is metabolized (up to 90%) in the organism by hepatic biotransformation into glucuronic acids and sulfonate conjugates, which are renally eliminated. Only 3–5% of PRC are excreted unmetabolized by the kidneys . Despite its high metabolization and considering its high prescription frequency, between 292 and 585 t of PRC is assumed to reach sewage treatment plants every year . In a recent study conducted by Kim et al. , the PRC concentration in wastewaters was shown to be less than 10 ng L−1 after biological treatment. Otherwise, this pharmaceutical was detected in sewage treatment plant effluents at concentrations up to 6 μg L−1 in another study . Many authors also investigated the occurrence of PRC in the aquatic environment . In surface waters, low concentrations ranging from 4 to 73 ng L−1 were documented . Although concentrations are usually low, the presence of this biologically active molecule in the aquatic environment may still affect aquatic organisms (especially upon long-term exposure) . Effects on fish cell line BF-2 and Daphnia, with EC50 (half maximal effective concentration) values ranging from 19 to 50 mg L−1, were reported for PRC . Lower toxicities were observed on luminescent bacteria Vibrio fisheri, algae, ciliates or fish embryos with an EC50 ranging from 112 to 920 mg L−1. Measures aimed at reducing the environmental exposure of pharmaceuticals have to be studied in order to avoid potential adverse effects. Ozonation is a current well known advanced water treatment strategy and its potential for pharmaceutical removal is thus of interest. Ozone is a strong oxidant used in drinking water and wastewater treatment plants to remove microorganisms, inorganic ions and organic pollutants . During ozonation, like other advanced oxidation processes (such as H2O2/UV), HO radicals that are known to be highly reactive oxidants can be generated. In recent years, several investigations have focused on the removal of pharmaceuticals at laboratory and pilot scales. The efficacy of oxidative treatment against pharmaceuticals in drinking water has been demonstrated . In the case of levofloxacin, a study investigated the oxidation by ozone and hydroxyl radicals generated by H2O2/UV system. From this work, a 1.38 s half-life can be expected during ozonation of water for a residual ozone concentration of 0.4 mg/L . Similarly, the oxidation of PRC in aqueous solution by ozonation and H2O2 photolysis was studied . According to Andreozzi et al. , PRC could be completely removed by the two systems, with mineralization rates of up to 30% for ozonation and 40% for H2O2 photolysis. Some transformation products were identified. In a secondary effluent, according to Kim et al. , the removal efficiency of PRC by direct photolysis was shown to be 1%, while the H2O2/UV process would enable 90% PRC removal. In the present work, the kinetic of PRC oxidation by ozonation and H2O2/UV processes were studied. Ozone rate constants (kO3/PRC) were determined using the competitive kinetic method with phenol (PHN) as competitor. The H2O2/UV oxidation system was chosen to determine the rate constant of hydroxyl radicals on PRC (kHO /PRC). A model of PRC degradation during ozonation in real waters was developed on the basis of these results. The identification of ozonation transformation products was investigated. Finally, the toxicity on V. fisheri was monitored for the first time. Transformation product formation and toxicity variations were also compared.
Materials and methods
Chemicals and stock solutions

All chemicals were used without further purification. PRC, PHN and hydroquinone (HDQ) (over 98% purity) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Tert-butanol (99.5%) was obtained from Acros Organics. Phosphate buffers, colorimetric agents and reductants were supplied by Fisher Scientific and Prolabo. Solutions were prepared with MilliQ purified water (18.2 MΩ cm; Millipore). Stock solutions of PRC, PHN and HDQ were prepared daily at appropriate concentrations. A Trailigaz generator (100 W) was used to produce ozone from oxygen. Ozone stock solutions (11–21 mg O3 L−1) were prepared by bubbling ozone in a semi-continuous reactor (800 mL) containing MilliQ water. A commercial solution of hydrogen peroxide (30%) delivered by Fluka was used for the experiments with the H2O2/UV system.
Experimental setup for ozonation experiments
Kinetic study
Identification of transformation products and toxicity

Toxicity was monitored and transformation products were identified during ozonation experiments conducted in a 200 mL semi-batch reactor containing PRC solution (1 g L−1). This initial concentration was chosen on the basis of the EC50 and EC20 values of PRC towards V. fisheri determined in a preliminary toxicity test (EC50 = 0.56 and EC20 = 0.21 g L−1), in order to better assess the toxicity changes. Ozone was introduced continuously into the reactor during the experiment (flow rate: 6 mg min−1). The pH to 7.2 was adjusted with phosphate buffer (ionic strength = 0.2 M). 2 mL of solution were withdrawn and analysed by liquid chromatography (LC) at different time intervals to monitor transformation product formation. 0.5 mL of samples was also withdrawn for toxicity measurement in Lumistox 300.
Experimental setup for the H2O2/UV system

The rate constant of PRC with HO radicals was determined in order to evaluate the contribution of the HO radicals during ozonation. The photolysis of H2O2 was used to produce hydroxyl radicals, as indicated in Eq. (2): H2O2+2hν→2HO Experiments were performed at 20 °C in a cylindrical batch reactor (volume: V = 5 L; annular path length: l = 6.3 cm) equipped with a low pressure mercury vapour lamp (HANAU NN 40/20, monochromatic emission at 254 nm) enclosed in a quartz sleeve in axial position. The incident UV light intensity measured by chemical actinometry using hydrogen peroxide (0.05 M) as actinometer was equal to 10.1 × 10−6 E s−1. Due to the negligible pH effect on the kinetics of PRC removal in the H2O2/UV system for pH < 7.5, the experiments were conducted in unbuffered solutions (pH = 5). At regular irradiation time intervals, samples were withdrawn for analyses of PRC and H2O2. To determine the rate constant of HO with PRC, high concentrations of H2O2 relative to PRC were introduced so that the UV radiation would mainly be absorbed by H2O2. Eq. (3) was validated. R=εH2O2[H2O2]0εH2O2[H2O2]0+εPRC[PRC]T,0>0.95 where [H2O2]0 = 50 mM, [PRC]T,0 = 5 μM, εPRC = 7891 M−1 cm−1 at 254 nm and pH 5 (determined in this work) and εH2O2 = 18.6 M−1 cm−1 at 254 nm and pH < 9. Consequently, the production of the hydroxyl radicals from the photolysis of H2O2 (Eq. (2)) could be easily approximated by Eq. (4): d[HO ]dt=-2d[H2O2]dt≈-2φH2O2I0V1-10-εH2O2l[H2O2] where, I0 = 10.1 × 10−6 E s−1, the incident photon flux; V = 5 L, the volume of the reactor; φH2O2=0.5, the quantum yield of H2O2 photolysis at 254 nm; l = 6.3 cm, the path length in the 5 L cylindrical reactor. Under these high H2O2 concentration conditions, the HO radicals formed are consumed mostly by H2O2. Then, assuming that kHO /H2O2[H2O2]0>50kHO /PRC[PRC]T,0, the consumption of HO radicals is formulated as: -d[HO ]dt≈kH2O2/HO [H2O2][HO ] From the steady-state hypothesis for radical species, the expression of the concentration of HO is found: [HO ]ss=2φH2O2I0/V(1-10-εH2O2l[H2O2])kH2O2/HO [H2O2] Moreover, when the concentration of H2O2 is high, H2O2 removal by photolysis and by reaction with HO radicals follows zero-order kinetics (-d[H2O2]/dt=2φH2O2I0/V). It was calculated that, for [H2O2]0 ≈ 50 mM, the global rate of H2O2 removal was below 150 μmol min−1. Therefore, the H2O2 concentration was considered constant over the experimental time (8 min) and [HO ]ss could be determined from Eq. (6). Consequently, under these experimental conditions, the kinetics of the removal of PRC by HO radicals become a pseudo-first-order expression and can be easily integrated: -d[PRC]Tdt=kHO /PRC[HO ]ss[PRC]T=kobs[PRC]T -ln[PRC]T,t[PRC]T,0=kobst The second-order rate constant (kHO /PRC) can be determined from the [HO ]ss concentration (Eq. (6)) and from the slope kobs of the straight line ln ([PRC]T,t/[PRC]T,0) = f(t).
Analytical methods

Hydrogen peroxide concentrations were measured by iodometry or the colorimetric titane (IV) method , depending on the concentration levels. Dissolved ozone concentrations were obtained with the Indigo method . pH was measured with a MeterLab pH meter (pH never varied by more than 0.2 units during the experiments). An Alliance Waters 2695 LC system equipped with a Kromasil C18 column (250 mm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm) and a UV–visible Waters 2487 detector was used to monitor residual PRC, PHN and HDQ. The injected volume was 100 μL and UV detection at 242, 275 and 290 nm was used for PRC, PHN and HDQ, respectively. A water/methanol mixture (80/20 v/v acidified with formic acid 0.1%) was used as mobile phase with a 1 mL min−1 flow rate. For the identification of degradation products, samples were analysed by LC/UV and mass spectrometry analyses (LC/MS and MS/MS). A Thermo chromatographic system (pump + thermostated autosampler Surveyor) equipped with a diode array detector (Thermo electron) and an ion trap mass spectrometer (Thermo DECA XP Ion max) was used. All analyses were carried out with a Kromasil C18 column (3.2 × 250 mm, 5 μm). The mobile phase consisted of a water/methanol mixture (90/10 v/v acidified with acetic acid 0.1%) with a flow-rate of 0.3 mL min−1. For each sample, the injection volume was 100 μL. Mass spectrometry analyses were performed with atmospheric pressure chemical ionisation (APCI) in both positive and negative mode. A mass range TIC of 50-550 amu, an ion transfer capillary temperature of 250 °C, an APCI vaporizer temperature of 450 °C, a sheath gas flow of 32 au and a Corona discharge of 5 μA were used. For MS/MS analyses, an isolation width of 2 amu, an activation time of 30 ms, an activation Q of 0.25 and a normalized collision energy of 35% of the voltage amplitude applied to the end-cap electrode were used. A luminescence test using V. fisheri bacteria (NRRLB-11177) was used to assess the toxicity of PRC and ozonation transformation products. Lyophilized bacteria were first reactivated in 2% NaCl solution and kept at 15 °C. PRC samples were prepared in aqueous solutions containing 2% NaCl for EC20 and EC50 determination according to the European standards NF/EN/ISO 11348-3 . Bacteria luminescence was measured before sample addition (0 min) and after 30 min incubation time with a luminometer (Lumistox 300). A similar protocol was used (with or without sample dilution) to estimate the solution toxicity after ozonation. For each sample, the salt concentration was adjusted to 2% by adding solid NaCl in each ozonated sample.
Results
Reaction with ozone

The competition kinetic method described above (paragraph 2.2.1) was used to determine the rate constants of ozone at pH 7.2. Fig. 1a presents a graph of ln [PRC]T,n/[PRC]T,0 versus ln [PHN]T,n/[PHN]T,0 obtained for different ozonation experiments performed at pH 7.2. This graph shows linear plots with correlation coefficients higher than 0.98. The second order rate constant of PRC was determined from Eq. (1) and the calculated phenol rate constant at pH 7.2 (kO3/PHN = 2.75 × 106 M−1 s−1). A value of 2.57 (±0.16) × 106 M−1 s−1 was obtained at pH 7.2. These results indicated fast removal of PRC by ozone and they were consistent with the second-order rate constant calculated from previously published data (kO3/PRC = 6.51 × 106 M−1 s−1 at pH 7.2 ). Ozone rate constants at a given pH usually depend on micropollutant speciation. In the case of PRC, two species were present in solutions according to the pKa value of its phenol function (pKa PRC = 9.38 ). The amide functional group of PRC was not pH dependent within the pH range used in this study. Therefore, the elementary reactions of ozone with neutral and ionic species of PRC (Eqs. ) can induce a pH dependence of the global rate constant. O3+PRC→productsk1 O3+PRC-→productsk2 The oxidation on the aromatic ring of PRC is probably favored considering the weak reactivity of ozone towards the amide substituent of the molecule. Moreover, in the case of phenols, the phenoxide ion rate constant was found to be 105–106-fold higher than the neutral form due to the electron-donor properties . Accordingly, it could be reasonably assumed that k1 [PRC] ≪ k2 [PRC−] and Eq. (9) would have a negligible impact on the global PRC ozonation reaction at pH 7.2. When considering Eq. (10) as representing the only elementary reaction, the PRC ozonation kinetics at pH 7.2 can then be expressed as: -d[PRC]Tdt=kO3/PRC[PRC]T[O3] Or, -d[PRC]Tdt=k2[PRC-][O3]=k2αPRC-[PRC]T[O3] With [PRC]T = [PRC] + [PRC−] and αPRC-: deprotonated PRC fraction of total PRC. Considering Eqs. , the following expression of kO3/PRC can thus be formulated: kO3/PRC=k2KaPRC[H+]+KaPRC Based on this latter equation and considering the experimental rate constant (kO3/PRC = 2.57 × 106 M−1 s−1) obtained at pH 7.2, a value of 3.6 × 108 M−1 s−1 was determined for the intrinsic rate constant k2. This constant was lower but in the same order of magnitude as that (9.91 × 108 M−1 s−1) obtained by Andreozzi et al. . Fig. 1b represents the pH profile modelled from Eq. (13) and the k2 value obtained in this study. For comparison, this figure also shows the modelled pH profiles obtained by taking reactions (9) and (10) and elementary rate constants obtained by Andreozzi et al. into account (i.e. considering k1 = 1.41 × 103 M−1 s−1 and k2 = 9.91 × 108 M−1 s−1). Good correlations between the two models were obtained, suggesting a negligible impact of reaction (9) in the 4–12 pH range.
Reaction with HO

The kinetics of PRC degradation by hydroxyl radicals were studied using the H2O2/UV system in the presence of an excess of H2O2 ([H2O2] = 50 mM) relative to the initial PRC concentration. Under these conditions, the H2O2 concentration was found constant during the irradiation (under 5% variation). The contribution of PRC photolysis by UV was modelled as indicated in Eqs. . -d[PRC]Tdt=φPRCI0VεPRC[PRC]TεH2O2[H2O2]+εPRC[PRC]T1-10-(εPRCl[PRC]+εH2O2l[H2O2]) -d[PRC]Tdt=φPRCI0VεPRC[PRC]TεH2O2[H2O2] ln[PRC]T,n[PRC]T,0=-φPRCI0VεPRCεH2O2[H2O2]t where, ΦPRC is the quantum yield of photolysis of PRC determined in this study and found to be equal to 3.46 × 10−3 mol mol−1 at pH 5. As shown in Fig. 2, direct photolysis of PRC was negligible in the H2O2/UV system with high H2O2 concentrations. The linear time-course variations in ln ([PRC]T,t/[PRC]T,0) in the H2O2/UV system confirmed the pseudo-first-order rate law described by Eq. (8) (Fig. 2).The second-order kinetic rate constant kHO /PRC was then calculated from the slope of ln ([PRC]T,t/[PRC]T,0) = f(t). The value for kHO /PRC was found to be 4.94 (±0.2) × 109 M−1 s−1 at pH 5. This value was higher but in the same order of magnitude than the rate constant mentioned in the literature at pH 5.5 and obtained from initial [PRC]T,0 ranging from 5 to 20 × 10−6 M and [H2O2]0 < 15 mM (kHO /PRC = 2.2 × 109 M−1 s−1).
Modelling PRC ozonation in natural waters

Hydroxyl radicals resulting from the reaction between ozone and hydroxide ions can be generated during ozonation. Therefore, pollutants can be degraded by either direct attack of the molecular ozone or indirect attack of the hydroxyl radicals. Consequently, the kinetics of PRC oxidation during ozonation of water can be formulated as follows: -d[PRC]Tdt=kHO /PRC[HO ][PRC]T+kO3/PRC[O3][PRC]T O3 and hydroxyl radical concentrations in addition to the corresponding rate constants are needed to predict PRC degradation during ozonation in real waters. O3 concentrations can be readily measured with standard methods. However, HO concentrations are difficult to determine. In water, they are usually very low and vary depending on the natural water considered. Then, the Rct concept in which the Rct is defined by the ratio of HO exposure to O3 exposure (Rct = ∫[HO ]dt/∫[O3]dt) can be used . According to Elovitz and von Gunten , Rct is constant in water during ozonation after an initial phase. Thus, Rct also represents the ratio of the HO radical concentration to the ozone concentration and Eq. (17) yields Eqs. . -d[PRC]Tdt=(kHO /PRC·Rct+kO3/PRC)[O3][PRC]T ln[PRC]T,t[PRC]T,0=-(kHO /PRC·Rct+kO3/PRC)∫[O3].dt=-(kHO /PRC·Rct+kO3/PRC)Ct This approach has been commonly used in previous studies to predict the degradation of pollutants and the formation of their oxidation products during ozonation. Rct values ranging from 10−9 to 10−7 are reported for natural waters . PRC degradation during ozonation at pH 7.2 was modelled by considering these two Rct values and Eq. (19) (Fig. 3). In this figure, the kHO /PRC value obtained at pH 5 was considered since no pH-dependence was expected. The results showed no impact of Rct on the kinetics of PRC degradation, thus confirming that the HO contribution in the kinetics of PRC ozonation was negligible under water treatment conditions. These results indicate that complete PRC removal could be expected in water treatment plants for ozone exposure far below 5 mg min L−1. A half-life of 0.03 s was estimated for an ozone concentration of 0.4 mg L−1.
Ozonation product identification and toxicity

Ozonation experiments were performed with an initial PRC concentration of 1 g L−1 to better assess the toxicity pattern during oxidation. These experiments were performed without tert-butanol since it was shown that the HO radical contribution could be neglected during ozonation. Under these conditions, the ozone mass balance showed a O3 consumption rate of 0.92 mg/mg of PRC.
Product identification and reaction pathway

Three transformation products (I, II, III) were observed by LC/UV, MS and MS/MS analyses during PRC ozonation (after oxidation times ranging from 5 to 90 min). The overall UV, MS and MS/MS characteristics of the transformation products and PRC peaks are given in Table 1. Only the positive APCI mode is presented due to the higher response obtained in positive mode for both PRC and transformation products. Note that, among these compounds, product I was not observed during MS analysis. Therefore, identification of this product was based on its UV spectra and its hydroquinone structure is proposed (Table 1). This was confirmed by the analysis of a standard solution of hydroquinone. The MS spectra of product II showed a protonated molecular ion at m/z 168. For this product, MS/MS fragmentation of m/z 168 gave ions at m/z 150 (−18), 126 (−42) and 108 (−60), which could correspond to H2O, CH2CO and (H2O + CH2CO) loss, respectively. Therefore, the chemical structure presented in Table 1 was proposed for product II. Due to the +16 mass difference between the molecular ion of this product and PRC, hydroxylation in the ortho position of PRC was assumed during ozonation. This structure is in agreement with the transformation products previously observed for PRC and other phenolic compounds . For product III, a molecular ion at m/z 200 showing a mass difference of (+48) with respect to molecular ion of PRC was observed. Ion fragments at m/z 182(−18), 172(−28), 158 (−42), 154(−46) and 140 (−60), which could correspond to a loss of H2O, CH2CO and (H2O + CO), were detected in MS/MS analyses of m/z 200. The structure presented in Table 1 was thus proposed for product III based on previously published data on the ozonation of PRC or other phenolic compounds . The reaction pathways presented in Fig. 4 could explain the observed transformation product formation . This suggested an initial ozone attack on the aromatic ring by electrophilic substitution. This first attack would occur: either on the ortho position to the phenolic function, giving product II and then product III after 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition followed by ring cleavage. or on the para position to the phenolic function, leading to hydroquinone.
Formation of transformation products and toxicity study

The toxicity and transformation product patterns are presented in Fig. 5a. The results showed that 90% of PRC was degraded after 25 min of ozonation, while a gradual increase in toxicity up to nearly 64% inhibition of luminescence bacteria was observed after less than 20 min. Moreover, all transformation products were completely degraded whereas 12% inhibition was still observed after 60 min of ozonation. Ozone could not account for the observed toxicity since no residual ozone was measured before the toxicity tests. According to previous data, HDQ was known to be highly toxic towards V. fisheri bacteria, with an EC50 of 0.08 mg L−1. A comparison of the transformation products and percentage inhibition patterns during the first 60 min of ozonation suggested that HDQ might be responsible for the observed toxicity. Additional toxicity tests were conducted with an aqueous HDQ solution to confirm this hypothesis. A much higher EC50 (7.42 mg L−1) than that obtained by Calza et al. was obtained for this compound. Based on the variation in the percentage inhibition versus HDQ concentrations (results not presented), the theoretical percentage of inhibition variation corresponding to luminescence inhibition caused by HDQ formation during the ozonation experiments was then estimated. Fig. 5b presents the variations in the hydroquinone concentration and the observed and theoretical percentage inhibition as a function of the ozonation time. This figure shows that the theoretical percentage inhibition was lower than that observed. Actually, hydroquinone may account for 11.4% of inhibition, whereas 60% inhibition was measured after 20 min ozonation according to these results. Other transformation products toxic to V. fisheri were thus assumed to have been formed. These products could correspond to products II and III or other products not detected under our experimental conditions, e.g. hydrogen peroxide which was previously detected during PRC ozonation by Andreozzi et al. . Similarly, additive effects with other transformation products can be suggested during ozonation.
Conclusions

PRC oxidation by ozone and hydroxyl radicals was investigated in pure water using ozonation and H2O2/UV processes. High rate constants were obtained for both systems (kO3/PRC = 2.57 × 106 M−1 s−1 and kHO /PRC = 4.94 × 109 M−1 s−1). PRC removal during ozonation under real water conditions was modelled on the basis of the Rct concept. Under these conditions, a half-life of 0.03 s can be expected for PRC for a residual ozone concentration of 0.4 mg L−1. Due to the high ozone rate constant, PRC degradation would mostly occur via molecular ozone reaction under water treatment conditions. Hydroxyl radical concentrations generated during ozonation of real waters is usually very low. Despite their high rate constant with PRC, hydroxyl radicals would not participate significantly in the PRC oxidation during ozonation. Three transformation products, including hydroquinone and hydroxylated derivatives of PRC, were observed. Finally, an increase in toxicity that could be partly assigned to hydroquinone formation was clearly observed during PRC ozonation.
